Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54106-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
 
Enhancing Knowledge as Public Goods for Project 
Innovation, Demonstration, and Replication
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EAOD  –  Office of the Director-General, East Asia Department 
  EARD  –  East Asia Department 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RKSI  –  Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TASF  –  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 08122020112203402056 Generated Date: 06-Jan-2021 16:33:39 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will enhance knowledge sharing; 
contribute to increased capacity of policy makers and project managers; and promote innovation, 
demonstration, and replicability of development projects among Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
developing member countries (DMCs). The TA will support knowledge sharing through the 
identification, capture, and sharing of innovative practices and lessons from ADB's engagement 
with the People's Republic of China (PRC). Dissemination will be done through knowledge 
products; multimedia products; and knowledge events such as trainings, workshops, and field 
visits for government officials from other DMCs. The TA will explore new collaboration with 
external  institutions  and  enable  close  coordination  among  ADB  operations  departments  in 
identifying and designing these knowledge activities. 
 
2.  While the TA is not included in the current country operations business plan for the PRC, 
2019–2021, it is in line with the country operations business plan priority of developing knowledge 
products that can be shared with other developing economies.1 The TA will support the new 
country partnership strategy and the country knowledge plan being developed for the PRC for 
2021–2025. The new strategy and the plan note that ADB's future policies, strategies, and 
projects to support the generation and dissemination of knowledge—both within the PRC and 
across the region—will be identified, designed, and delivered through TA and partnerships with 
government counterparts, research institutions, and centers of excellence.2 The TA is in line with 
Strategy  2030’s  operational  priority  of  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity, 
accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality,  and  addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing 
inequalities.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB has been engaging with the PRC to address remaining development challenges, 
especially on inclusive and sustainable growth; environment and climate change; and social and 
human development including health, aging, and education. ADB’s engagement emphasizes 
knowledge-based solutions as the PRC seeks to put its economy on a more sustainable trajectory 
while dealing with a wide array of complex issues (footnote 1).  
 
4.  During the knowledge retreat of the East Asia Department (EARD) in December 2019, 
management and staff from other ADB regional and knowledge departments emphasized the 
need to intensify collaboration among departments to capture and share the knowledge learned 
from the PRC’s development experience, and to replicate successful interventions in other DMCs. 
These departments expressed interest in learning from ADB’s engagement with middle-income 
countries, and from the PRC’s success in several areas.  
 
5.  While there have already been efforts to replicate and share good practices from ADB’s 
engagement in the PRC, there is still room to systematically capture and share these lessons. 
The need to strengthen the systematic documentation and dissemination of knowledge and 
lessons from ADB projects in the PRC was noted by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department 
in its country partnership strategy final review validation.4 While recognizing that knowledge 
sharing activities have contributed to the replication of successful projects, the report noted that 
 
1 ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2019–2021. Manila. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 September 2020. 
3 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  
4  Independent Evaluation Department. 2020. People’s Republic of China Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy 
Final Review, 2016–2020. Manila: ADB.

2   
these mostly “covered general knowledge from many different sources and were not focused on 
experiences from ADB demonstration projects in the PRC” (footnote 4). The report also noted the 
limited  systematic  efforts  to  document  knowledge  and  lessons  from  ADB’s  innovative 
demonstration projects in the PRC.  
 
6.  This TA aims to address the lack of a systematic process for ADB to capture and share 
project knowledge and increase interactions among DMCs and ADB departments. The TA will 
provide a venue to share project knowledge and experiences. By doing so, the TA (i) creates 
formal mechanisms to capture and share knowledge and innovative practices from ADB projects; 
(ii) effectively identifies, captures, and documents lessons and practices; and (iii) contributes to 
increased project knowledge of government officials from ADB DMCs. By strengthening these 
processes, the TA aims to contribute to the successful and innovative development practices 
across ADB DMCs, especially on project design and implementation.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: project design and implementation in ADB’s 
DMCs improved.5 The TA will have the following outcome: commitment of DMCs to integrate 
innovative  and  successful  practices  into  project  design  and  implementation  increased. 6 
Specifically, this TA aims to have at least two DMCs indicate their willingness to adopt innovative 
and successful practices from the PRC into one of their projects.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Cases and multimedia products on ADB projects in the People’s Republic 
of China produced. The TA will produce knowledge products, including cases and multimedia 
products on ADB projects in the PRC. It will help identify ADB-supported development projects in 
the PRC that can serve as demonstration projects to other DMCs. Knowledge products will be 
developed on these projects and published in various formats including publications, infographics, 
and multimedia products. These products will be disseminated through study visits and other 
knowledge events to help facilitate knowledge sharing among DMCs. These products will mostly 
be disseminated through digital means, although knowledge products may be printed per request 
of participating DMCs, especially when used in training and knowledge events, and when 
translated products are needed for wider dissemination within DMCs.  
 
9.  Output  2:  Lessons  from  ADB  projects  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China 
disseminated to other developing member countries. Dissemination of lessons from ADB 
projects in the PRC will be done through knowledge events that focus on areas where the PRC 
has a history of strong success, including urban development, poverty reduction, and rural 
development. The TA will also support an annual regional workshop with a selected special-
themed study that touches on emerging development issues facing the PRC. The special themes 
could include aging, public health, climate change, and environmental protection. This will serve 
as the main platform for creating and sharing knowledge relevant to the operations in the East 
Asia region and can cover both the strategic issues usually covered by the Regional Knowledge 
Sharing Initiative (RKSI) knowledge events, and project-based knowledge and experience. Virtual 
 
5  The impact is defined by the TA.  
6  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
or online training activities may also be conducted, given the uncertainty for physical meetings 
brought about by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.  
 
10.  Output  3:  Knowledge  and  understanding  of  government  officials  on  new  and 
innovative practices in project design strengthened. Training and knowledge events will be 
conducted to build the capacity of government officials from DMCs through the sharing of project-
based experience of the PRC. These activities could include training, workshops, and webinars, 
including train-the-trainers for government agencies. Study visits may also be conducted to allow 
government officials from other DMCs to learn from actual ADB projects in the PRC. These 
activities  will  primarily  focus  on  experiences  in  innovative  technologies  and  approaches  in 
implementing key projects in the PRC, and will involve interaction with project team leaders, local 
and national government officials, and beneficiaries of identified projects. Project consultants who 
were involved in implementing selected projects could also share their project experiences. 
Lessons from ADB projects in the PRC, both successes and failures, will also be shared in order 
to better understand what worked and what did not in (i) the PRC’s path to development and (ii) 
the collaboration between ADB and the PRC. Virtual or online training activities may also be 
conducted given the uncertainty for physical meetings brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. 
Study visits will be scheduled, keeping in mind the travel restrictions from the COVID-19 pandemic.  
 
11.  To identify ADB projects in the PRC that have strong demonstration effects, the Office of 
the Director General (EAOD) of EARD, in close coordination with ADB’s PRC Resident Mission 
and other ADB regional departments, will hold annual consultation meetings with government 
officials of the PRC and other DMCs to identify projects that have strong demonstration and 
replication potential. EAOD will also consult with other ADB regional and knowledge departments 
to identify specific areas in ADB operations in the PRC that are of interest to other DMCs.  
 
12.  To effectively promote demonstration and replication of the PRC’s project experience, a 
call for proposals will be opened to all ADB DMCs. The call for proposals will allow the TA to 
support activities proposed by other ADB departments that aim to capture innovative and good 
practices from projects in the PRC and encourage replication. The call for proposals will be 
opened to ADB departments at least twice per year. Considering inputs from the Government of 
the PRC and other ADB departments, EAOD will develop the criteria to evaluate and select 
activities and amounts to be supported by the TA.  
 
13.  The TA will build on the achievements of past TA, including EARD’s RKSI, which primarily 
draws on the PRC’s experience to facilitate exchange of development-related knowledge among 
ADB’s DMCs. This TA can complement current RKSI efforts by linking project-level discussions 
to RKSI’s discussions of strategic issues such as the PRC’s poverty reduction experience and its 
5-year plans. In particular, the TA provides a new knowledge sharing platform through an annual 
flagship regional knowledge sharing event to share crosscutting and thematic issues and project-
based learnings and experiences. The knowledge products developed through the TA could be 
shared through various channels, such as the Development Asia website, which was established 
with the support of the TA for Knowledge Solutions.7 Likewise, knowledge products that address 
strategic development issues identified in the PRC and Mongolia under the TA for Supporting 
Strategic Knowledge Products and Research Networking could be used as learning materials 
during workshops and trainings.8 Existing regional platforms, such as  the Greater Mekong 
Subregion and Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, as well as knowledge sharing 
platforms, such as the RKSI, the ADB Institute, and CAREC Institute, will be effectively used.  
 
7 ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Knowledge Solutions. Manila.  
8 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and Research Networking. Manila.

4   
 
14.  Given the cross-regional nature of the study, the TA approach is most appropriate to 
effectively  liaise  across  DMCs  and  ADB  departments  in  identifying  needs  and  designing 
appropriate knowledge products and events. To monitor the impact of these events and outputs, 
pre- and post-activity evaluations will be conducted. Close coordination with other participating 
regional and knowledge departments will also be undertaken at least 6 months and 1 year after 
these activities to monitor impacts of the TA. Attention will be paid to how lessons from the TA 
activities have contributed to or have been replicated in other ADB projects.       
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF) ($250,000 from TASF 6, and $250,000 from TASF-
other sources) and the People’s Republic of China’s Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation 
Fund9 ($500,000).The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
16.  The People’s Republic of China’s Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund will 
finance operational expenses related to TA and other eligible initiatives agreed upon by the MOF 
PRC and ADB, including consulting services, training conferences, workshops small-scale civil 
works and/or other associated demonstration level equipment and materials.  
 
17.  The governments will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA. EAOD, in coordination with the ADB PRC Resident Mission, 
will hold annual consultations with the Government of the PRC in identifying demonstration 
projects that the DMCs can possibly learn from and replicate. EAOD will lead discussions with 
ADB regional and knowledge departments to identify areas where DMCs are interested to learn 
from the PRC operations experience. EAOD will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; 
organize  workshops;  oversee  the  publication  of  knowledge  products;  evaluate  and  select 
proposals from other DMCs to be supported by the TA; and provide staff to act as resource 
persons in the knowledge and capacity development activities, as necessary.   
 
19.  Cofinancier requirements. ADB will provide PRC Fund with periodic reports (e.g., 
progress reports, additional updates on project implementation) and support the fund’s visibility 
as outlined in the PRC Fund Contribution Agreement (2017) and its implementation guidelines. 
For major changes in project scope, duration, or funding arrangements, the TA team will circulate 
draft memos to the Partner Funds Division of the ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate 
Change Department for review prior to approval. 
 
20.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented from 21 December 2020 to 21 December 2023. ADB will be 
the executing agency of the TA, with ADB’s EAOD as the implementing agency. 
  
 
  
9 The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper.

5

22.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants, as needed, following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.10  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China 
Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 ($250,000 from TASF-6 and $250,000 from TASF-other 
sources) on a grant basis for Enhancing Knowledge as Public Goods for Project Innovation, 
Demonstration, and Replication, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
 
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Cases and multimedia products on ADB projects in the People’s Republic of China produced

1.3. Engage consultants to produce knowledge products (Q2 2021–Q2 2023) 
1.4. Finalize knowledge products (Q3 2021–Q3 2023) 
2.  Lessons from ADB projects in the People’s Republic of China disseminated to other developing 
member countries 
2.1. Identify social media and other platforms to disseminate knowledge products (Q1 2021–Q4 2023) 
2.2. Identify training and/or workshop where cases and products can be used and discussed (Q1 2021–
2023) 
2.3. Upload knowledge products in identified platforms (Q4 2021–Q4 2023) 
2.4. Organize knowledge events within ADB to share lessons from ADB projects in the PRC, including 
virtual or online training and seminars, given the uncertainty brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic 
(Q3 and Q4 of 2021, 2022, and Q2 2023)  
3. Knowledge and understanding of government officials on new and innovative practices in project 
design strengthened

2023)

workshops and/or field visits are conducted, and as needed
